questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a history of mild pain in his right shoulder following a minor fall. The X-ray is shown below. There is no significant swelling or erythema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Simple Bone Cyst (SBC) / Unicameral bone cyst

A solitary, usually unilocular, cystic bone cavity filled with serous or serosanguinous fluid and lined by a fibrous membrane.

Epidemiology

Age: Presents in the first two decades of life.

Sex: More common in males. (2:1)

Location

Commonly affects the metaphysis close to the physis.

Most frequently occurs in the proximal humerus, proximal femur, and proximal tibia.

Presentation

Often asymptomatic, discovered incidentally.

Pathological fracture is a common presentation.

Types

Active cyst: If the cyst is situated close to the epiphyseal plate.

Latent cyst: If the cyst moves away from the growth plate.

Radiological Features

X-ray:

Well-outlined, lytic lesion located centrally in the metaphysis.

Expands and thins the cortex.

Fallen leaf sign: a small bone fragment within the cyst cavity following a fracture

Trap-door sign: a small bone fragment hinges at the cortex.

 

MRI: Homogeneous, fluid-filled cavity.

Histology

Connective tissue lining with foci of reactive bone.

It has characteristic giant cells.

Treatment

Percutaneous steroid injections for active lesions.

Curettage and bone grafting.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of the indicated arrow?
questions.explanation:
Vascular
  • Haemophilia and other bleeding disorders
  • Myeloid metaplasia (thrombocytopenia)
  • Erythroblastic anemias
  • Leukaemias
  • Varicose veins
  • Hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy
  • Pachydermoperiostosis

Physiologic
  • Prematurity

Dysplastic
  • Melorheostosis
  • Engelmann's disease

Traumatic
  • Local subperiosteal trauma
  • Fractures (including march fractures)
  • Unrecognized skeletal trauma (Caffey's syndrome)

Hypo/Hypervitaminosis
  • Rickets
  • Scurvy
  • Hypervitaminosis A

Infective
  • Acute osteomyelitis (staphylococcal, streptococcal, pneumococcal)
  • Brodie's abscess
  • Tuberculosis
  • Syphilis (congenital and acquired)

Neoplastic
  • Primary:
    • Benign :meningioma, angioma, osteoid osteoma
    • Malignant: osteogenic sarcoma (only this is called Codman's triangle), fibrosarcoma, Ewing's sarcoma
  • Secondary: metastatic bony deposits

Endocrine
  • Thyroid acropachy
  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Secondary hyperparathyroidism in renal osteodystrophy

Primary Joint Lesions
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Juvenile chronic arthritis (Still's disease)
  • Reiter's syndrome
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Osteoarthritis (femoral neck only)

Congenital
  • Tuberous sclerosis

Miscellaneous
  • Infantile cortical hyperostosis
  • Histiocytosis

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the clinic for a routine check-up. During the visit, he shared his family history of bone tumors, mentioning that several relatives have passed away from various types of bone cancers. Concerned about his own risk, he asks the doctor which type of bone malignancy he should be most vigilant about.

A 15-year-old girl comes to the clinic with persistent pain and swelling in her right knee that has been worsening over the past few months. During her family history discussion, her mother recalls that a distant relative had primary bone cancer in their youth. Concerned about the possibility of a serious condition, the girl asks the doctor which type of bone malignancy is most commonly seen in adolescents like her.
questions.explanation:
Type

Osteogenic Sarcoma (Osteosarcoma)

Origin

Most common primary malignant bone tumor of non-hematopoietic origin

Tissue Origin

Solid malignant bone tumor

Age Group

Bimodal distribution: peaks in adolescence (10–14 years) and again in the seventh decade

Gender Prevalence

More common in males than females

Common Sites

1. Lower end of femur

2. Upper end of tibia

Location of Origin

Arises from the metaphysis of long bones

questions.text: All of the following are correctly matched bone tumors except? 1. Most common bone tumors Secondaries 2. Most common primary benign bone tumor Osteoblastoma 3. Most common primary malignant bone tumor Osteogenic sarcoma. 4. Most Common bone tumor in elderly Multiple myeloma.
questions.explanation:
1. Most common bone tumors

Secondaries from:

  • Prostrate
  • Breast
  • Kidney
  • Thyroid
  • Lung

Pb KTL (Lead Kettle)

2. Most common primary benign bone tumor

Osteochondroma

3. Most common primary malignant bone tumor

Osteogenic sarcoma.

4. Most Common bone tumor in elderly

Multiple myeloma.

Also Called

Exostosis

Type

Most common primary benign bone tumor

Structure

An offshoot from spongy bone tissue with a cartilaginous cap

Cause

Due to unwanted activity of the cambium layer of the periosteum

Most Common Age

Growth period (teenagers, during growth spurts)

Gender Preponderance

Male

Most Common Site

Lower end of the femur

2nd Common Site

Upper end of the tibia

Location

Around the knee joint; commonly around the metaphysis of long bones and crest of ilium

questions.text: A 70-year-old female presents with a two-week history of left thumb pain and swelling. She has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and triple-negative carcinoma of mammary origin, diagnosed five years prior. Physical examination reveals swelling and mild ulceration at the distal first phalanx. The X-ray is shown below. What is the most common underlying cause of the patient's thumb lesion?
questions.correct_answer: B. Secondary carcinoma from another site
questions.explanation:
Common Metastatic Tumors
  • Lung carcinoma (male)
  • Breast carcinoma (female)
  • Prostate carcinoma (Osteoblastic)
  • Thyroid carcinoma

Clinical Features
  • Known Primary Malignancy:
    • Bone pain (common in spine, ribs, extremities)
    • Pathological fracture (common in spine)
 
  • Unknown Primary Malignancy:
    • Bone pain leading to destructive lesion diagnosis
    • Pathological fracture due to weakened bone

Malignancies Presenting with Silent Primary
  • Thyroid carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Bladder carcinoma

Common Sites of Metastasis
  • Vertebral bodies
  • Ribs
  • Pelvis
  • Humerus
  • Femur
  • Uncommon distal to elbow and knee

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with a one-year history of progressively worsening thigh pain, initially accompanied by intermittent fevers and malaise. Recently, her pain has intensified to the point of bedridden status. She develops acute confusion and altered consciousness, with laboratory tests revealing severe hypercalcemia and elevated alkaline phosphatase. An X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Ewing's Sarcoma

Multiple Myeloma (Plasmacytoma)

Age Group Affected

4–25 years

40–60 years

Sex Distribution

More common in males

Equally affects males and females

Primary Site

Long bones (femur, tibia, fibula, humerus)

Bone (typically spine, skull, pelvis, ribs)

Location

Diaphysis of long bones

Various bones, often vertebrae

Symptoms

Intermittent pain, worse at night, fever

Severe back pain, weakness, weight loss

Physical Examination

Fixed tumor, red skin, dilated veins

Local tenderness, possible pathological fractures

Radiographic Features

Lytic, sclerotic, or mixed lesions; periosteal onion peel appearance; moth-eaten destruction

Diffuse osteoporosis, lytic lesions; biconcave vertebrae; punched-out lesions in skull and pelvis

Histological Features

Sheets of small, uniform cells resembling lymphocytes; pseudo-rosettes may be present

Round cells with eccentrically placed nuclei; sparse chromatin arranged in a “spokes of wheel” pattern; perinuclear halo typically not seen

Prognosis

Poor 5-year survival rate

Variable, but generally better than Ewing's

Common Complications

Metastasis to lungs and other organs

Pathological fractures, neurological symptoms

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of worsening back pain, fatigue, and significant weight loss. He also reports frequent headaches, difficulty concentrating, and numbness in his legs. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the lumbar spine and decreased sensation in the lower extremities. Laboratory investigations show normocytic anemia, hypercalcemia, and elevated serum creatinine. Urinalysis reveals the presence of Bence Jones proteins. A skeletal survey is done. Which of the following is NOT a typical radiological feature of the patient’s most likely condition?
questions.correct_answer: D. Sunburst appearance in long bones

questions.text: A 25-year-old male has pain and progressive swelling around the proximal part of the left hand for the last 3 months. The X-ray is shown below. A biopsy reveals small, round cells forming pseudo-rosettes. Which of the following is not correct regarding the diagnosis of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a highly malignant tumor of bone, commonly involving diaphysis.

options.label: C
options.text: The tumor is highly radio-sensitive but prone to recurrence.

options.label: D
options.text: Males are more likely to be affected than females.

questions.correct_answer: B. Bone-to-bone metastasis is not common.
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:

questions.text: A 27-year-old female is diagnosed with a giant cell tumor in her distal femur after presenting with vague pain and swelling. She undergoes surgical excision of the tumor. Which of the following pre-operative X-ray findings is most consistent with giant cell tumors?

A 32-year-old woman presents with progressive and persistent vague pain and swelling around her right knee for the past 3 months. On physical examination, there is swelling around the distal femur with tenderness. Histopathology shows multinucleated giant cells and spindle-shaped mononuclear stromal cells. Which of the following statements is true regarding the nature of the tumor in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: It commonly arises from the diaphysis of long bones

options.label: B
options.text: It is benign but can behave aggressively locally

options.label: C
options.text: It most frequently metastasizes to regional lymph nodes

options.label: D
options.text: It most commonly affects individuals under the age of 20

questions.correct_answer: B. It is benign but can behave aggressively locally

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to orthopedics OPD with mild fever and intermittent thigh pain for the past several months, particularly at night. There is no history of fever and weight loss. On physical exam, there is swelling and tenderness over the distal femur. An X-ray image is shown below. Which of the following best explains the radiological finding in osteosarcoma that is marked with an arrow in the above image?

options.label: B
options.text: It represents tumor calcification within the bone

options.label: C
options.text: It is a result of the tumor breaking through the periosteum, lifting it off the bone

options.label: D
options.text: It indicates early metastasis to the nearby soft tissue

questions.correct_answer: C. It is a result of the tumor breaking through the periosteum, lifting it off the bone

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with swelling and pain around her left ankle for the past 6 months. The pain is worse at night and unresponsive to analgesics. On examination, there is a firm, poorly defined, tender mass over the distal femur, with shiny skin and prominent veins over the swelling. The X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is true regarding the most common site of origin for the bone tumor that the patient is having in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow

questions.text: Match column A (cell type) with column B (tumor) according to the Lichtenstein Classification of bone tumors. Column A Column B 1. Bone a. Giant cell tumor 2. Cartilage b. Eosinophilic granuloma 3. Bone marrow c. Exostosis 4. Uncertain d. Osteoid osteoma
questions.explanation:
Cell Type

Benign

Malignant

Bone

Osteoid osteoma

Osteosarcoma

Cartilage

Chondroma or Enchondroma

Osteochondroma or exostosis

Chondrosarcoma

Fibrous Tissue

Fibroma

Fibrosarcoma

Bone Marrow

Eosinophilic granuloma

Ewing's sarcoma

Multiple myeloma

Vascular

Haemangioma

Angiosarcoma

Uncertain

Giant cell tumor

(osteoclastoma)

Malignant giant cell tumor

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with pain and swelling over the distal radius. X-ray shows an expansile lytic lesion in the epiphysis extending to the metaphysis. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) reveals a bloody aspirate with hemosiderin-laden macrophages. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC)

Giant Cell Tumor (GCT)

Age

Primarily affects children and teenagers

Most common in young adults (15-35 years)

Gender

Equal distribution between males and females

More common in females (Female: Male ratio 1.5:1)

Location

Metaphyses of long bones (femur, tibia, humerus), spine

Epiphyses of long bones (lower end of femur, upper end of tibia)

Symptoms

Pain and swelling; spinal lesions may cause neurological issues

Swelling without pain; late stages show joint limitation and pathological fracture

Histology

FNAC: Hemosiderin +

Blood-filled cystic spaces separated by fibrous septae

FNAC: No hemosiderin

Abundant giant cells with multiple nuclei (>150), spindle cells indicating malignancy

Radiology

Osteolytic lesion, multiple septations and fluid-fluid levels on MRI

Thin septa with soap-bubble appearance on X-ray, cortex thin and expanded, no periosteal reaction

Treatment

Curettage, debridement, and in some cases radiation (cautiously)

Surgical excision with PMMA or bone grafting; Denosumab and bisphosphonates as adjunct therapy

questions.text: A 15-year-old female presents with a gradually enlarging, painful swelling over the distal femur. On examination, the swelling is tender and firm. X-ray shows an expansile, lytic lesion with multiple fluid levels in the metaphysis. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC)

A benign, expansile bone lesion composed of blood-filled cystic spaces.

Epidemiology

Primarily affects children and teenagers (10 to 30 years).

Males > Females

Location

Metaphyses of long bones (femur, tibia, humerus).

Located subperiosteally.

Presentation

Pain and Swelling.

Radiological Features

X-ray: Radiolucent area situated at the metaphysis.

Osteolytic, poorly defined lesion elevating and eroding the cortex.

MRI: Multiple intralesional septations and fluid levels.

Angiography: Persistence of contrast and a blush of flow within the lesion.

Histology

Composed of blood-filled cystic spaces separated by fibrous septae.

In chronic cases, the septae may contain woven bone.

Treatment

Surgery: Curettage and bone grafting

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a history of a slowly growing, painless swelling on the forehead for the past 3 years. On examination, a hard, immobile mass is palpated. A CT scan shows a dense, well-circumscribed, bony lesion in the frontal sinus. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with persistent pain in his right leg, which is worse at night and relieved by ibuprofen. Physical examination is unremarkable, with no swelling or warmth over the affected area. An X-ray of the right leg is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Osteoid Osteoma

A small, benign bone tumor composed of osteoid and woven bone with a surrounding halo of reactive bone

Demographics
  • Sex: Males > Females
  • Age: Young patients, but rare under 5 years and over 30.

Location
  • The diaphysis of long bones, especially the proximal tibia, and femur.
  • It can also occur in the spine, particularly the posterior arches.

Pathophysiology

The nidus releases prostaglandins which cause the characteristic pain that relieves on taking NSAIDs

Symptoms
  • Characterized by pain, often worse at night (Night crises), and relieved by NSAIDs (Therapeutic test).
  • When near joints, it may cause stiffness and effusion.
  • In the spine, it can lead to muscle spasms and scoliosis.

Radiology

X-Ray:

  • Dense sclerosis with a small, rounded area of osteolysis, often obscured by the surrounding sclerosis.
  • The characteristic lesion is less than 1.5 cm in diameter with a sclerotic margin and radiolucent nidus.

Isotope bone scans (Best investigation) are positive

Histology
  • Consists of a mesh of woven bone, osteoblastic rimming, osteoclasts, and dilated capillaries.
  • The mature osteoid forms the nidus, surrounded by dense, reactive bone and soft tissue with inflammatory changes.

Treatment
  • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation.
  • Surgical excision of the nidus (gold standard)

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with mild, intermittent knee pain for 6 months. X-ray shows an eccentric, lytic lesion in the proximal tibial metaphysis without periosteal reaction. Biopsy reveals stellate cells in a myxoid background. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Chondromyxoid Fibroma

The least common, benign cartilaginous bone tumor

Demographics

Sex: Slightly more common in males.

Age: Teenagers and young adults (2nd and 3rd decade of life).

Location

Metaphyses of long bones,

particularly the proximal tibia and pelvis.

Presentation

Slow-growing swelling with pain

Radiology

X-ray:

Small, metaphyseal, eccentric lytic lesions, lying parallel to the bone's long axis.

The cortex is expanded, thin, and interrupted. Medullary margins are scalloped and sclerosed.

 

It erupts through the cortex with minimal periosteal or soft tissue reaction.

 

Histology

Stellate cells on a myxoid background. Mitotic figures are rare, though cellular atypia may occur.

Treatment

Small tumors: Local excision and bone grafting

large tumors: Wide en bloc excision

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with localized pain and joint stiffness around the knee. Radiographic examination reveals a well-defined lytic lesion in the epiphysis of a long bone. Histological analysis shows a "wet-sawdust" appearance and "chicken-wire" calcification. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is most commonly diagnosed in patients over 35 years of age.

options.label: B
options.text: They are confined within the epiphyses of long bones.

options.label: C
options.text: Recurrence occurs in approximately 10% of cases after treatment.

options.label: D
options.text: It is more prevalent in females compared to males.

questions.correct_answer: C. Recurrence occurs in approximately 10% of cases after treatment.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Prevalence

< 1% of all bone neoplasms

Age Distribution

Peak incidence at 10-20 years; rare <10 or >35 years

Gender

More prevalent in males than females (Option D ruled out)

Feature

Description

Appearance

Well-defined, round or oval lytic lesions

Size

Typically 1 to 7 cm

Cortical Expansion

May show expansion without breach

MRI Characteristics

Homogeneous high-signal lesions

Treatment

Description

Curettage

Tumor scraping with/without bone grafting

Radiofrequency Ablation

Minimally invasive heat treatment

En-bloc Resection

Aggressive removal with healthy margin for recurrence

Joint Preservation

Focus on maintaining adjacent joint integrity

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with a well-defined, radiolucent lesion in the distal phalanx of the hand. Radiographic findings reveal rounded, lobulated edges with characteristic "popcorn-like" opacities. The lesion measures 4 cm in diameter and is asymptomatic. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate management for this condition?

An X-ray image shows multiple large chondromas in the hands and feet of a 28-year-old female patient. Based on this radiological finding, which of the following statements is false regarding her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of large chondromas may indicate a higher risk of malignant transformation.

options.label: B
options.text: These chondromas can lead to bone expansion and thinning of the cortex.

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical excision of all chondromas is the standard treatment to prevent malignant transformation.

options.label: D
options.text: Patients with multiple chondromas have an increased risk of extra-skeletal malignancies

questions.correct_answer: C. Surgical excision of all chondromas is the standard treatment to prevent malignant transformation.
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:

Feature

Details

Clinical Presentation

Usually diagnosed in childhood

Most chondromas found in phalangeal bones

Common findings:

Asymmetric limb shortening

Swelling of fingers/toes

Impaired movement of interphalangeal joints

Distribution

Can be unilateral or bilateral

Progression

New chondromas typically stop after puberty

Tumor growth in adulthood may indicate malignancy

Risk of pathological fractures

Malignant Transformation

20-30% risk of secondary chondrosarcoma

Transformation usually occurs in the 30s or 40s

Warning signs:

Increase in size of existing chondroma

New symptoms

Feature

Details
   

Clinical Presentation

Multiple chondromas with hemangiomas



 

Symptoms can appear at birth or later

Radiographic Features

X-rays show large chondromas


 

Possible bone expansion and cortex thinning (Option B ruled out)

Malignant Transformation

Risk of secondary chondrosarcoma > 50% (Option A ruled out)

Similar timing for malignant transformation as Ollier's disease

Increased risk for carcinomas (breast, liver, ovary) (Option D ruled out)

Radiographic Appearance

Large chondromas visible on X-rays

Histological Features

Higher cellularity and proliferative potential compared to solitary chondromas


 

Feature

Details

Malignant Transformation

Concern for secondary sarcoma in both conditions

Signs:

Increase in lesion size

New symptoms (e.g., pain)

MRI evidence of new soft-tissue mass

Histological permeative growth pattern

Extra-skeletal Malignancies

Higher risk for tumors in breast, liver, ovaries, CNS

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is diagnosed with a chondroma following imaging and histological examination. Which of the following statements regarding chondromas is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Chondromas are generally slow-growing, ceasing post-skeletal maturity.

options.label: B
options.text: Most chondromas are symptomatic and present with pain or fractures.

options.label: C
options.text: Chondromas commonly occur in the tubular bones of the hand.

options.label: D
options.text: Serial X-rays can help monitor for malignant transformation in chondromas.

questions.correct_answer: B. Most chondromas are symptomatic and present with pain or fractures.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Location

Predominantly found in tubular bones of the hand. (Option C ruled out)

Other common sites include the femur and humerus.

Symptoms

Mostly asymptomatic; often discovered via radiography.

May cause pain or pathological fractures in some cases.

Growth

Generally slow-growing, ceasing post-skeletal maturity. (Option A ruled out)

Malignant Transformation

Typically benign, but differentiation from low-grade chondrosarcoma (grade 1) is challenging.

Indicators of chondrosarcoma include:

Increased cellularity

Enlarged nuclei

Presence of multiple double-nucleated cells

Infiltration into marrow spaces and haversian system

Serial X-rays are useful for monitoring potential malignancy; growth post-skeletal maturity may signal transformation. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a bony swelling near his knee. He denies pain or any recent trauma. X-ray shows a pedunculated bony outgrowth growing away from the joint, with a thin outer cortex and cancellous structure. What is the next step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: MRI to assess the cartilage cap thickness

questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:

Complication

Description

Painful bursa formation

Due to friction over the osteochondroma.

Activity-related discomfort

General discomfort with movement.

Nerve compression

Rare, may cause neuropathic symptoms.

Fracture

Uncommon, results in sudden pain.

Malignant transformation

Rare progression to chondrosarcoma, more likely with a cartilage cap >1.5 cm.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presents with a painless, hard mass near his proximal humerus. Imaging reveals a bony protuberance with a well-defined cortex that flares into the lesion. Which of the following radiographic features is most indicative of osteochondroma?

options.label: D
options.text: Joint erosion adjacent to the lesion

questions.correct_answer: B. Cortical flaring into the lesion
questions.explanation:
Type

Characteristics

Risk of Malignant Transformation

Solitary Osteochondroma

Low risk (~1%). Difficult to determine exact incidence.

~1%

Multiple Osteochondromas (MO)

Higher risk (~4%). Autosomal dominant disorder with EXT1 or EXT2 gene mutations in 90% of cases.

~4%
